statistics.name: assists
statistics.description: The number of times a player who passes the ball to a teammate in a way that leads to a score by field goal, meaning that he or she was "assisting" in the basket. There is some judgment involved in deciding whether a passer should be credited with an assist.

statistics.name: turnovers
statistics.description: The number of times a player loses possession to the other team.

statistics.name: minutes
statistics.description: The total number of minutes played.

statistics.name: assistTurnoverRatio
statistics.description: The average number of assists a player or team records per turnover

statistics.name: rebounds
statistics.description: The total number of rebounds (offensive and defensive).

statistics.name: defensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the defense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot by the offense.

statistics.name: offensiveRebounds
statistics.description: The number of times when the offense obtains the possession of the ball after a missed shot.

article.headline: Colorado 81, Baylor 48
article.story: BOULDER, Colo. (AP) -- Ricardo Patton couldn't tell if Baylor's lack of a non-conference schedule was the difference in a lopsided win, but he saw improvement in his top two scorers, Richard Roby and Chris Copeland. Richard Roby scored 21 points and Copeland added 17 on four 3-pointers as Colorado dealt Baylor its 17th consecutive loss by winning 81-48 Wednesday night. The Bears have played only three games this season after NCAA violations forced the elimination of their non-conference schedule. "I can't tell you if they showed signs of rustiness," Patton said. "I do know that without a non-conference schedule of games, it has to have some effect." Andy Osborn also had 12 points for Colorado (12-3, 2-2 Big 12 Conference). The Buffaloes have beaten Baylor six straight times at home, last losing to the Bears here on Dec. 15, 1951. "The one thing I've learned is you have to play hard no matter who you are playing," Roby said. "It doesn't matter what the color of the other uniform is." Roby did most of his damage from the perimeter, with 8-for-17 shooting, two 3-pointers to go with seven rebounds. Although Copeland had four, 3-pointers, the remainder of his contribution came inside the paint. "We don't have a big presence," Patton said. "Chris is the best we have at going hard around the basket." Henry Dugat led Baylor (0-3, 0-3) with 10 points. The team's leading scorer, Aaron Bruce had nine points and didn't score until hitting a 3-pointer a little over a minute into the second half. Baylor never appeared to be in sync in shooting 25 percent for the game and finishing 10-for-19 at the free throw line. They led only briefly and that was early on in the game. Colorado led 36-18 at halftime after starting slowly, missing 5-of-6 six shots to start the game. Baylor capitalized and with baskets by Henry Dugat and Tim Bush led 12-7, but following a timeout Osborn and Roby hit 3-pointers for Colorado to make it 13-12 and the Buffaloes never trailed again. "There was a time when Richard had one foot in and one foot out of the door so to speak," Patton said of Roby. "He's certainly settled in since then and gotten to where he should be." Roby had seven of Colorado's 23 points over the final 10:12 of the half while Baylor managed only two field goals and a pair of free throws over that span. Curtis Jerrells hit 1-of-2 throws ahead of a 11-2 run for Colorado, four points coming from Roby, to increase the Buffaloes lead to 60-36 with 7:40 remaining. "One of our keys was our defense of Bruce," Patton said of the Baylor sophomore who averages over 15 points a game. "We wanted to make sure he never left our sights and aside for when he got free to hit two, 3-pointers, he didn't."
